name: Peshawari Naan
history: Peshawari Naan originates from Peshawar, Pakistan, and has become a popular variety of naan in Indian and Pakistani cuisines. It's known for its sweet filling, typically consisting of nuts and dried fruits, which adds a unique flavor to the bread.
description: Peshawari Naan is a rich and sweet naan bread stuffed with a delightful mixture of dried fruits, nuts, and spices. It's traditionally baked in a tandoor but can also be made in an oven or on a stove. This naan is often enjoyed with creamy curries.

ingredients.item: filling: mixed dried fruits (raisins, apricots, etc.) and nuts (almonds, cashews, etc.), chopped

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Mix flour, yeast or baking powder, sugar, and salt in a bowl. Add milk, yogurt, and melted butter or ghee to form a soft dough. Knead well and let it rest for about 2 hours until it doubles in size.

instructions.title: Make the Filling
instructions.description: Combine the chopped dried fruits, nuts, desiccated coconut, and cardamom powder in a bowl.

instructions.title: Stuff and Shape the Naan
instructions.description: Divide the dough into balls. Roll each ball into a circle, place some filling in the center, and seal it. Roll it again gently into an oval shape.

instructions.title: Bake the Naan
instructions.description: Place the naan in a preheated oven or tandoor. Bake until puffed up and golden brown. Optionally, brush with butter or ghee after baking.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Peshawari Naan hot, ideally with a savory curry or as a standalone snack.

tips: Ensure the dough is soft and pliable for the best texture.
The filling should be finely chopped to distribute evenly in the naan.
variations: Add a pinch of saffron for an aromatic flavor.
Experiment with different nuts and dried fruits according to your preference.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh. Can be stored for up to 1 day in the refrigerator.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container and reheat in the oven before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in the oven or on a tawa until warm.
presentationTips: Serve on a traditional Indian platter with accompaniments like chutney.
Garnish with a sprinkle of chopped nuts for added texture.
